elements.description:
The angular damping value for the collision object. Setting this value alters the damping of
angular motion of the object (rotation). Valid values are between 0 (no damping) and 1 (full damping).
elements.examples:
How to decrease a collision object component's angular damping: 
-- get angular damping from collision object "collisionobject" in gameobject "floater"
local target = "floater#collisionobject"
local damping = go.get(target, "angular_damping")
-- decrease it by 10%
go.set(target, "angular_damping", damping * 0.9)
elements.name: angular_damping

elements.description: The current angular velocity of the collision object component as a vector3. The velocity is measured as a rotation around the vector with a speed equivalent to the vector length in radians/s.
elements.examples:
How to query and modify a collision object component's angular velocity: 
-- get angular velocity from collision object "collisionobject" in gameobject "boulder"
local velocity = go.get("boulder#collisionobject", "angular_velocity")
-- do something interesting
if velocity.z < 0 then
    -- clockwise rotation
    ...
else
    -- counter clockwise rotation
    ...
end
-- decrease it by 10%
velocity.z = velocity.z * 0.9
go.set("boulder#collisionobject", "angular_velocity", velocity * 0.9)
elements.name: angular_velocity

elements.brief: applies a force on a collision object
elements.description:
Post this message to a collision-object-component to apply the specified force on the collision object.
The collision object must be dynamic.
elements.examples:
Assuming the instance of the script has a collision-object-component with id "co": 
-- apply a force of 1 Newton towards world-x at the center of the game object instance
msg.post("#co", "apply_force", {force = vmath.vector3(1, 0, 0), position = go.get_world_position()})
elements.name: apply_force

parameters.doc: the force to be applied on the collision object, measured in Newton
parameters.name: force

parameters.doc: the position where the force should be applied
parameters.name: position

elements.brief: reports a collision between two collision objects in cases where a listener is specified.
elements.description: See physics.set_listener. This message is sent to a function specified in physics.set_listener when two collision objects collide. This message only reports that a collision has occurred and will be sent once per frame and per colliding pair. For more detailed information, check for the contact_point_event.
elements.examples:
How to take action when a collision occurs: 
physics.set_listener(function(self, event, data)
  if event == hash("collision_event") then
      pprint(data)
      -- {
      --  a = {
      --          group = hash: [default],
      --          position = vmath.vector3(183, 666, 0),
      --          id = hash: [/go1]
      --      },
      --  b = {
      --          group = hash: [default],
      --          position = vmath.vector3(185, 704.05865478516, 0),
      --          id = hash: [/go2]
      --      }
      -- }
  end
end)
elements.name: collision_event

parameters.doc:
collision information for object A
position
vector3 The world position of object A
id
hash The ID of object A
group
hash The collision group of object A
parameters.name: a

parameters.doc:
collision information for object B
position
vector3 The world position of object B
id
hash The ID of object B
group
hash The collision group of object B
parameters.name: b

elements.brief: reports a collision between two collision objects
elements.description: This message is broadcasted to every component of an instance that has a collision object, when the collision object collides with another collision object. For a script to take action when such a collision happens, it should check for this message in its on_message callback function. This message only reports that a collision actually happened and will only be sent once per colliding pair and frame. To retrieve more detailed information, check for the contact_point_response instead.
elements.examples:
How to take action when a collision occurs: 
function on_message(self, message_id, message, sender)
    -- check for the message
    if message_id == hash("collision_response") then
        -- take action
    end
end
elements.name: collision_response

parameters.doc: the id of the instance the collision object collided with
parameters.name: other_id

parameters.doc: the world position of the instance the collision object collided with
parameters.name: other_position

parameters.doc: the collision group of the other collision object
parameters.name: other_group

parameters.doc: the collision group of the own collision object
parameters.name: own_group

elements.brief: reports a contact point between two collision objects in cases where a listener is specified.
elements.description: See physics.set_listener. This message is sent to a function specified in physics.set_listener when a collision object has contact points with another collision object. Since multiple contact points can occur for two colliding objects, this event can be sent multiple times in the same frame for the same two colliding objects. To only be notified once when the collision occurs, check for the collision_event event instead.
elements.examples:
How to take action when a contact point occurs: 
physics.set_listener(function(self, event, data)
 if event == hash("contact_point_event") then
     pprint(data)
     -- {
     --  applied_impulse = 310.00769042969,
     --  distance = 0.0714111328125,
     --  a = {
     --      position = vmath.vector3(446, 371, 0),
     --      relative_velocity = vmath.vector3(1.1722083854693e-06, -20.667181015015, -0),
     --      mass = 0,
     --      group = hash: [default],
     --      id = hash: [/flat],
     --      normal = vmath.vector3(-0, -1, -0)
     --  },
     --  b = {
     --      position = vmath.vector3(185, 657.92858886719, 0),
     --      relative_velocity = vmath.vector3(-1.1722083854693e-06, 20.667181015015, 0),
     --      mass = 10,
     --      group = hash: [default],
     --      id = hash: [/go2],
     --      normal = vmath.vector3(0, 1, 0)
     --  },
     -- }
  end
end)
elements.name: contact_point_event

parameters.doc: the impulse the contact resulted in
parameters.name: applied_impulse

parameters.doc: the penetration distance between the objects, which is always positive
parameters.name: distance

parameters.doc:
contact point information for object A
position
vector3 The world position of object A
id
hash The ID of object A
group
hash The collision group of object A
relative_velocity
vector3 The relative velocity of the collision object A as observed from B object
mass
number The mass of the collision object A in kg
normal
vector3 normal in world space of the contact point, which points from B object towards A object
parameters.name: a

parameters.doc:
contact point information for object B
position
vector3 The world position of object B
id
hash The ID of object B
group
hash The collision group of object B
relative_velocity
vector3 The relative velocity of the collision object B as observed from A object
mass
number The mass of the collision object B in kg
normal
vector3 normal in world space of the contact point, which points from A object towards B object
parameters.name: b

elements.brief: reports a contact point between two collision objects
elements.description: This message is broadcasted to every component of an instance that has a collision object, when the collision object has contact points with respect to another collision object. For a script to take action when such contact points occur, it should check for this message in its on_message callback function. Since multiple contact points can occur for two colliding objects, this message can be sent multiple times in the same frame for the same two colliding objects. To only be notified once when the collision occurs, check for the collision_response message instead.
elements.examples:
How to take action when a contact point occurs: 
function on_message(self, message_id, message, sender)
    -- check for the message
    if message_id == hash("contact_point_response") then
        -- take action
    end
end
elements.name: contact_point_response

parameters.doc: world position of the contact point
parameters.name: position

parameters.doc: normal in world space of the contact point, which points from the other object towards the current object
parameters.name: normal

parameters.doc: the relative velocity of the collision object as observed from the other object
parameters.name: relative_velocity

parameters.doc: the penetration distance between the objects, which is always positive
parameters.name: distance

parameters.doc: the impulse the contact resulted in
parameters.name: applied_impulse

parameters.doc: life time of the contact, not currently used
parameters.name: life_time

parameters.doc: the mass of the current collision object in kg
parameters.name: mass

parameters.doc: the mass of the other collision object in kg
parameters.name: other_mass

parameters.doc: the id of the instance the collision object is in contact with
parameters.name: other_id

parameters.doc: the world position of the other collision object
parameters.name: other_position

parameters.doc: the collision group of the other collision object
parameters.name: other_group

parameters.doc: the collision group of the own collision object
parameters.name: own_group

elements.description:
The linear damping value for the collision object. Setting this value alters the damping of
linear motion of the object. Valid values are between 0 (no damping) and 1 (full damping).
elements.examples:
How to increase a collision object component's linear damping: 
-- get linear damping from collision object "collisionobject" in gameobject "floater"
local target = "floater#collisionobject"
local damping = go.get(target, "linear_damping")
-- increase it by 10% if it's below 0.9
if damping <= 0.9 then
    go.set(target, "linear_damping", damping * 1.1)
end
elements.name: linear_damping

elements.description:
The current linear velocity of the collision object component as a vector3.
The velocity is measured in units/s (pixels/s).
elements.examples:
How to query and modify a collision object component's linear velocity: 
-- get linear velocity from collision object "collisionobject" in gameobject "ship"
local source = "ship#collisionobject"
local velocity = go.get(source, "linear_velocity")
-- decrease it by 10%
go.set(source, "linear_velocity", velocity * 0.9)
-- apply the velocity on target game object "boulder"'s collision object as a force
local target = "boulder#collisionobject"
local pos = go.get_position(target)
msg.post(target, "apply_force", { force = velocity, position = pos })
elements.name: linear_velocity

elements.description: READ ONLY Returns the defined physical mass of the collision object component as a number.
elements.examples:
How to query a collision object component's mass: 
-- get mass from collision object component "boulder"
local mass = go.get("#boulder", "mass")
-- do something useful
assert(mass > 1)
elements.name: mass

elements.description:
Create a physics joint between two collision object components.
Note: Currently only supported in 2D physics.
elements.name: physics.create_joint

parameters.doc: the joint type
parameters.name: joint_type

parameters.doc: first collision object
parameters.name: collisionobject_a

parameters.doc: id of the joint
parameters.name: joint_id

parameters.doc: local position where to attach the joint on the first collision object
parameters.name: position_a

parameters.doc: second collision object
parameters.name: collisionobject_b

parameters.doc: local position where to attach the joint on the second collision object
parameters.name: position_b

parameters.doc: optional joint specific properties table See each joint type for possible properties field. The one field that is accepted for all joint types is: - boolean collide_connected: Set this flag to true if the attached bodies should collide.
parameters.name: [properties]

elements.description:
Destroy an already physics joint. The joint has to be created before a
destroy can be issued.
Note: Currently only supported in 2D physics.
elements.name: physics.destroy_joint

parameters.doc: collision object where the joint exist
parameters.name: collisionobject

parameters.doc: id of the joint
parameters.name: joint_id

elements.description:
Get the gravity in runtime. The gravity returned is not global, it will return
the gravity for the collection that the function is called from.
Note: For 2D physics the z component will always be zero.
elements.examples:
function init(self)
    local gravity = physics.get_gravity()
    -- Inverse gravity!
    gravity = -gravity
    physics.set_gravity(gravity)
end
elements.name: physics.get_gravity

elements.brief: returns the group of a collision object
elements.description: Returns the group name of a collision object as a hash.
elements.name: physics.get_group

parameters.doc: the collision object to return the group of.
parameters.name: url

returnvalues.doc:
hash value of the group. 
local function check_is_enemy()
    local group = physics.get_group("#collisionobject")
    return group == hash("enemy")
end
returnvalues.name: group

elements.description:
Get a table for properties for a connected joint. The joint has to be created before
properties can be retrieved.
Note: Currently only supported in 2D physics.
elements.name: physics.get_joint_properties

parameters.doc: collision object where the joint exist
parameters.name: collisionobject

parameters.doc: id of the joint
parameters.name: joint_id

returnvalues.doc:
properties table. See the joint types for what fields are available, the only field available for all types is:
  • boolean collide_connected: Set this flag to true if the attached bodies should collide.
returnvalues.name: properties

elements.brief: get the reaction force for a joint
elements.description:
Get the reaction force for a joint. The joint has to be created before
the reaction force can be calculated.
Note: Currently only supported in 2D physics.
elements.name: physics.get_joint_reaction_force

parameters.doc: collision object where the joint exist
parameters.name: collisionobject

parameters.doc: id of the joint
parameters.name: joint_id

elements.brief: get the reaction torque for a joint
elements.description:
Get the reaction torque for a joint. The joint has to be created before
the reaction torque can be calculated.
Note: Currently only supported in 2D physics.
elements.name: physics.get_joint_reaction_torque

parameters.doc: collision object where the joint exist
parameters.name: collisionobject

parameters.doc: id of the joint
parameters.name: joint_id

returnvalues.doc: the reaction torque on bodyB in N*m.
returnvalues.name: torque

elements.brief: checks the presense of a group in the mask (maskbit) of a collision object
elements.description:
Returns true if the specified group is set in the mask of a collision
object, false otherwise.
elements.name: physics.get_maskbit

parameters.doc: the collision object to check the mask of.
parameters.name: url

parameters.doc: the name of the group to check for.
parameters.name: group

returnvalues.doc:
boolean value of the maskbit. 'true' if present, 'false' otherwise. 
local function is_invincible()
    -- check if the collisionobject would collide with the "bullet" group
    local invincible = physics.get_maskbit("#collisionobject", "bullet")
    return invincible
end
returnvalues.name: maskbit

elements.description: Gets collision shape data from a collision object
elements.name: physics.get_shape

parameters.doc: the collision object.
parameters.name: url

parameters.doc: the name of the shape to get data for.
parameters.name: shape

returnvalues.doc:
A table containing meta data about the physics shape
type
number The shape type. Supported values:
  • physics.SHAPE_TYPE_SPHERE
  • physics.SHAPE_TYPE_BOX
  • physics.SHAPE_TYPE_CAPSULE Only supported for 3D physics
  • physics.SHAPE_TYPE_HULL
The returned table contains different fields depending on which type the shape is. If the shape is a sphere:
diameter
number the diameter of the sphere shape
If the shape is a box:
dimensions
vector3 a vmath.vector3 of the box dimensions
If the shape is a capsule:
diameter
number the diameter of the capsule poles
height
number the height of the capsule
local function get_shape_meta()
    local sphere = physics.get_shape("#collisionobject", "my_sphere_shape")
    -- returns a table with sphere.diameter
    return sphere
end
returnvalues.name: table

elements.description: The following properties are available when connecting a joint of JOINT_TYPE_FIXED type:
elements.name: physics.JOINT_TYPE_FIXED

parameters.doc: The maximum length of the rope.
parameters.name: max_length

elements.name: physics.JOINT_TYPE_HINGE

parameters.name: joint_translation

parameters.doc: READ ONLYCurrent joint translation speed, usually in meters per second. (Read only field, available from physics.get_joint_properties())
parameters.name: joint_speed

elements.name: physics.JOINT_TYPE_SPRING

parameters.doc: The natural length between the anchor points.

elements.name: physics.JOINT_TYPE_WELD

parameters.doc: READ ONLYThe bodyB angle minus bodyA angle in the reference state (radians).
parameters.name: reference_angle

parameters.name: frequency

parameters.doc: The damping ratio. 0 = no damping, 1 = critical damping.
parameters.name: damping

elements.description: The following properties are available when connecting a joint of JOINT_TYPE_WHEEL type:
elements.name: physics.JOINT_TYPE_WHEEL

parameters.doc: The local translation unit axis in bodyA.
parameters.name: local_axis_a

parameters.doc: The maximum motor torque used to achieve the desired motor speed. Usually in N-m.
parameters.name: max_motor_torque

parameters.doc: The desired motor speed in radians per second.
parameters.name: motor_speed

parameters.doc: Enable/disable the joint motor.

parameters.name: frequency

parameters.doc: The spring damping ratio. 0 = no damping, 1 = critical damping.
parameters.name: damping

parameters.doc: READ ONLYCurrent joint translation, usually in meters. (Read only field, available from physics.get_joint_properties())
parameters.name: joint_translation

parameters.name: joint_speed

elements.brief: requests a ray cast to be performed
elements.description: Ray casts are used to test for intersections against collision objects in the physics world. Collision objects of types kinematic, dynamic and static are tested against. Trigger objects do not intersect with ray casts. Which collision objects to hit is filtered by their collision groups and can be configured through groups.
elements.examples:
How to perform a ray cast synchronously: 
function init(self)
    self.groups = {hash("world"), hash("enemy")}
end

function update(self, dt)
    -- request ray cast
    local result = physics.raycast(from, to, self.groups, {all=true})
    if result ~= nil then
        -- act on the hit (see 'ray_cast_response')
        for _,result in ipairs(results) do
            handle_result(result)
        end
    end
end
elements.name: physics.raycast

parameters.doc: the world position of the start of the ray
parameters.name: from

parameters.doc: the world position of the end of the ray
parameters.name: to

parameters.doc: a lua table containing the hashed groups for which to test collisions against
parameters.name: groups

parameters.doc:
a lua table containing options for the raycast.
all
boolean Set to true to return all ray cast hits. If false, it will only return the closest hit.
parameters.name: options

returnvalues.doc: It returns a list. If missed it returns nil. See ray_cast_response for details on the returned values.
returnvalues.name: result

elements.brief: requests a ray cast to be performed
elements.description:
Ray casts are used to test for intersections against collision objects in the physics world. Collision objects of types kinematic, dynamic and static are tested against. Trigger objects do not intersect with ray casts. Which collision objects to hit is filtered by their collision groups and can be configured through groups. The actual ray cast will be performed during the physics-update.
  • If an object is hit, the result will be reported via a ray_cast_response message.
  • If there is no object hit, the result will be reported via a ray_cast_missed message.
elements.examples:
How to perform a ray cast asynchronously: 
function init(self)
    self.my_groups = {hash("my_group1"), hash("my_group2")}
end

function update(self, dt)
    -- request ray cast
    physics.raycast_async(my_start, my_end, self.my_groups)
end

function on_message(self, message_id, message, sender)
    -- check for the response
    if message_id == hash("ray_cast_response") then
        -- act on the hit
    elseif message_id == hash("ray_cast_missed") then
        -- act on the miss
    end
end
elements.name: physics.raycast_async

parameters.doc: the world position of the start of the ray
parameters.name: from

parameters.doc: the world position of the end of the ray
parameters.name: to

parameters.doc: a lua table containing the hashed groups for which to test collisions against
parameters.name: groups

parameters.doc: a number between [0,-255]. It will be sent back in the response for identification, 0 by default
parameters.name: [request_id]

elements.description:
Set the gravity in runtime. The gravity change is not global, it will only affect
the collection that the function is called from.
Note: For 2D physics the z component of the gravity vector will be ignored.
elements.examples:
function init(self)
    -- Set "upside down" gravity for this collection.
    physics.set_gravity(vmath.vector3(0, 10.0, 0))
end
elements.name: physics.set_gravity

parameters.doc: the new gravity vector
parameters.name: gravity

elements.brief: change the group of a collision object
elements.description:
Updates the group property of a collision object to the specified
string value. The group name should exist i.e. have been used in
a collision object in the editor.
elements.name: physics.set_group

parameters.doc: the collision object affected.
parameters.name: url

parameters.doc:
the new group name to be assigned. 
local function change_collision_group()
     physics.set_group("#collisionobject", "enemy")
end
parameters.name: group

elements.brief: flip the geometry horizontally for a collision object
elements.description: Flips the collision shapes horizontally for a collision object
elements.examples:
function init(self)
    self.fliph = true -- set on some condition
    physics.set_hflip("#collisionobject", self.fliph)
end
elements.name: physics.set_hflip

parameters.doc: the collision object that should flip its shapes
parameters.name: url

parameters.doc: true if the collision object should flip its shapes, false if not
parameters.name: flip

elements.description:
Updates the properties for an already connected joint. The joint has to be created before
properties can be changed.
Note: Currently only supported in 2D physics.
elements.name: physics.set_joint_properties

parameters.doc: collision object where the joint exist
parameters.name: collisionobject

parameters.doc: id of the joint
parameters.name: joint_id

parameters.doc: joint specific properties table Note: The collide_connected field cannot be updated/changed after a connection has been made.
parameters.name: properties

elements.brief: sets a physics world event listener. If a function is set, physics messages will no longer be sent.
elements.description: sets a physics world event listener. If a function is set, physics messages will no longer be sent.
elements.examples:
local function physics_world_listener(self, event, data)
  if event == hash("contact_point_event") then
    pprint(data)
    -- {
    --  distance = 0.0714111328125,
    --  applied_impulse = 310.00769042969,
    --  a = {
    --      position = vmath.vector3(446, 371, 0),
    --      relative_velocity = vmath.vector3(1.1722083854693e-06, -20.667181015015, -0),
    --      mass = 0,
    --      group = hash: [default],
    --      id = hash: [/flat],
    --      normal = vmath.vector3(-0, -1, -0)
    --  },
    --  b = {
    --      position = vmath.vector3(185, 657.92858886719, 0),
    --      relative_velocity = vmath.vector3(-1.1722083854693e-06, 20.667181015015, 0),
    --      mass = 10,
    --      group = hash: [default],
    --      id = hash: [/go2],
    --      normal = vmath.vector3(0, 1, 0)
    --  }
    -- }
  elseif event == hash("collision_event") then
    pprint(data)
    -- {
    --  a = {
    --          group = hash: [default],
    --          position = vmath.vector3(183, 666, 0),
    --          id = hash: [/go1]
    --      },
    --  b = {
    --          group = hash: [default],
    --          position = vmath.vector3(185, 704.05865478516, 0),
    --          id = hash: [/go2]
    --      }
    -- }
  elseif event ==  hash("trigger_event") then
    pprint(data)
    -- {
    --  enter = true,
    --  b = {
    --      group = hash: [default],
    --      id = hash: [/go2]
    --  },
    --  a = {
    --      group = hash: [default],
    --      id = hash: [/go1]
    --  }
    -- },
  elseif event ==  hash("ray_cast_response") then
    pprint(data)
    --{
    --  group = hash: [default],
    --  request_id = 0,
    --  position = vmath.vector3(249.92222595215, 249.92222595215, 0),
    --  fraction = 0.68759721517563,
    --  normal = vmath.vector3(0, 1, 0),
    --  id = hash: [/go]
    -- }
  elseif event ==  hash("ray_cast_missed") then
    pprint(data)
    -- {
    --  request_id = 0
    --},
  end
end

function init(self)
    physics.set_listener(physics_world_listener)
end
elements.name: physics.set_listener

parameters.doc:
A callback that receives information about all the physics interactions in this physics world.
self
object The calling script
event
constant The type of event. Can be one of these messages:
  • contact_point_event
  • collision_event
  • trigger_event
  • ray_cast_response
  • ray_cast_missed
data
table The callback value data is a table that contains event-related data. See the documentation for details on the messages.
parameters.name: callback

elements.brief: updates the mask of a collision object
elements.description: Sets or clears the masking of a group (maskbit) in a collision object.
elements.name: physics.set_maskbit

parameters.doc: the collision object to change the mask of.
parameters.name: url

parameters.doc: the name of the group (maskbit) to modify in the mask.
parameters.name: group

parameters.doc:
boolean value of the new maskbit. 'true' to enable, 'false' to disable. 
local function make_invincible()
    -- no longer collide with the "bullet" group
    physics.set_maskbit("#collisionobject", "bullet", false)
end
parameters.name: maskbit

elements.description:
Sets collision shape data for a collision object. Please note that updating data in 3D
can be quite costly for box and capsules. Because of the physics engine, the cost
comes from having to recreate the shape objects when certain shapes needs to be updated.
elements.name: physics.set_shape

parameters.doc: the collision object.
parameters.name: url

parameters.doc: the name of the shape to get data for.
parameters.name: shape

parameters.doc:
the shape data to update the shape with. See physics.get_shape for a detailed description of each field in the data table. 
local function set_shape_data()
    -- set capsule shape data
    local data = {}
    data.diameter = 10
    data.height = 20
    physics.set_shape("#collisionobject", "my_capsule_shape", data)

    -- set sphere shape data
    data = {}
    data.diameter = 10
    physics.set_shape("#collisionobject", "my_sphere_shape", data)

    -- set box shape data
    data = {}
    data.dimensions = vmath.vector3(10, 10, 5)
    physics.set_shape("#collisionobject", "my_box_shape", data)
end
parameters.name: table

elements.brief: flip the geometry vertically for a collision object
elements.description: Flips the collision shapes vertically for a collision object
elements.examples:
function init(self)
    self.flipv = true -- set on some condition
    physics.set_vflip("#collisionobject", self.flipv)
end
elements.name: physics.set_vflip

parameters.doc: the collision object that should flip its shapes
parameters.name: url

parameters.doc: true if the collision object should flip its shapes, false if not
parameters.name: flip

elements.brief: updates the mass of a dynamic 2D collision object in the physics world.
elements.description:
The function recalculates the density of each shape based on the total area of all shapes and the specified mass, then updates the mass of the body accordingly.
Note: Currently only supported in 2D physics.
elements.examples: physics.update_mass("#collisionobject", 14)
elements.name: physics.update_mass

parameters.doc: the collision object whose mass needs to be updated.
parameters.name: collisionobject

parameters.doc: the new mass value to set for the collision object.
parameters.name: mass

elements.description:
Collision objects tend to fall asleep when inactive for a small period of time for
efficiency reasons. This function wakes them up.
elements.name: physics.wakeup

parameters.doc:
the collision object to wake. 
function on_input(self, action_id, action)
    if action_id == hash("test") and action.pressed then
        physics.wakeup("#collisionobject")
    end
end
parameters.name: url

elements.description: This message is sent back to the sender of a ray_cast_request, or to the physics world listener if it is set (see physics.set_listener), if the ray didn't hit any collision object. See physics.raycast_async for examples of how to use it.
elements.name: ray_cast_missed

parameters.doc: id supplied when the ray cast was requested
parameters.name: request_id

elements.description: This message is sent back to the sender of a ray_cast_request, or to the physics world listener if it is set (see physics.set_listener), if the ray hits a collision object. See physics.raycast_async for examples of how to use it.
elements.name: ray_cast_response

parameters.doc: the fraction of the hit measured along the ray, where 0 is the start of the ray and 1 is the end
parameters.name: fraction

parameters.doc: the world position of the hit
parameters.name: position

parameters.doc: the normal of the surface of the collision object where it was hit
parameters.name: normal

parameters.doc: the instance id of the hit collision object
parameters.name: id

parameters.doc: the collision group of the hit collision object as a hashed name
parameters.name: group

parameters.doc: id supplied when the ray cast was requested
parameters.name: request_id

elements.brief: reports interaction (enter/exit) between a trigger collision object and another collision object
elements.description: See physics.set_listener. This message is sent to a function specified in physics.set_listener when a collision object interacts with another collision object and one of them is a trigger. This message only reports that an interaction actually happened and will be sent once per colliding pair and frame. For more detailed information, check for the contact_point_event.
elements.examples:
How to take action when a trigger interaction occurs: 
physics.set_listener(function(self, event, data)
 if event ==  hash("trigger_event") then
     if data.enter then
        -- take action for entry
     else
        -- take action for exit
     end
     pprint(data)
     -- {
     --  enter = true,
     --  b = {
     --      group = hash: [default],
     --      id = hash: [/go2]
     --  },
     --  a = {
     --      group = hash: [default],
     --      id = hash: [/go1]
     --  }
     -- },
  end
end)
elements.name: trigger_event

parameters.doc: if the interaction was an entry or not
parameters.name: enter

parameters.doc:
interaction information for object A
id
hash The ID of object A
group
hash The collision group of object A
parameters.name: a

parameters.doc:
collision information for object B
id
hash The ID of object B
group
hash The collision group of object B
parameters.name: b

elements.brief: reports interaction (enter/exit) between a trigger collision object and another collision object
elements.description: This message is broadcasted to every component of an instance that has a collision object, when the collision object interacts with another collision object and one of them is a trigger. For a script to take action when such an interaction happens, it should check for this message in its on_message callback function. This message only reports that an interaction actually happened and will only be sent once per colliding pair and frame. To retrieve more detailed information, check for the contact_point_response instead.
elements.examples:
How to take action when a trigger interaction occurs: 
function on_message(self, message_id, message, sender)
    -- check for the message
    if message_id == hash("trigger_response") then
        if message.enter then
            -- take action for entry
        else
            -- take action for exit
        end
    end
end
elements.name: trigger_response

parameters.doc: the id of the instance the collision object collided with
parameters.name: other_id

parameters.doc: if the interaction was an entry or not
parameters.name: enter

parameters.doc: the collision group of the triggering collision object
parameters.name: other_group

parameters.doc: the collision group of the own collision object
parameters.name: own_group
